articles.headline: For Venezuela, a Treasure in Oil Sludge
articles.snippet: As oil prices soar, Venezuela's Orinoco Belt, which may contain up to 235 billion barrels of recoverable oil, is becoming an economic battleground.
articles.abstract: As oil prices soar, Venezuela's Orinoco Belt, which may contain up to 235 billion barrels of recoverable oil, is becoming an economic battleground.

articles.headline: Terror Fears Hamper U.S. Muslims' Travel
articles.snippet: Humiliation and periodic roughing up have prompted some U.S. Muslims to avoid traveling as much as possible.
articles.abstract: Humiliation and periodic roughing up have prompted some U.S. Muslims to avoid traveling as much as possible.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, May 31 — Azhar Usman, a burly American-born Muslim with a heavy black beard, says he elicits an almost universal reaction when he boards an airplane at any United States airport: conversations stop in midsentence and the look in the eyes of his fellow passengers says, "We're all going to die!"

articles.headline: Iraq's Premier Seeks to Control a City in Chaos
articles.snippet: Once seemingly immune to the violence that has plagued the rest of the country, Basra Province  has sunk into chaos.
articles.abstract: Once seemingly immune to the violence that has plagued the rest of the country, Basra Province  has sunk into chaos.
articles.lead_paragraph: BASRA, Iraq, May 31 — Iraq's new prime minister made an urgent visit to this increasingly lawless city on Wednesday, imposing a state of emergency and ordering leaders to cease their violent struggle for power and allow order to return to this oil-rich region.
articles.byline: By Sabrina Tavernise and Qais Mizher

articles.headline: Saks Fifth Avenue Takes a Step Back in Search of Its Future
articles.snippet: Of all the changes that unfolded under the three-year reign of Fred Wilson, none left shoppers scratching their heads more than the elimination of Real Clothes.
articles.abstract: Of all the changes that unfolded under the three-year reign of Fred Wilson, none left shoppers scratching their heads more than the elimination of Real Clothes.
articles.lead_paragraph: Of all the changes that unfolded at Saks Fifth Avenue under the tumultuous three-year reign of Fred Wilson, none left shoppers and investors scratching their heads more than the elimination of Real Clothes, a popular in-house clothing label.

articles.headline: U.S. Makes Offer to Meet Iranians on Nuclear Plan
articles.snippet: The Bush administration is willing to join Europeans in talks with Iran over its nuclear program if it suspends all nuclear activities.
articles.abstract: The Bush administration is willing to join Europeans in talks with Iran over its nuclear program if it suspends all nuclear activities.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 31 — The Bush administration said Wednesday that the United States would join Europeans in talks with Iran over its nuclear program, but only if Tehran first suspended its uranium activities, which are thought to be a cover for developing nuclear arms.

articles.headline: Big Bonuses Still Flow, Even if Bosses Miss Goals
articles.snippet: Executive compensation often exceeds the amounts allowed under the performance targets set by directors.
articles.abstract: Executive compensation often exceeds the amounts allowed under the performance targets set by directors.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was the kind of mistake that wage slaves can only dream of. Because of what the company called an "improper interpretation" of his employment contract, Sheldon G. Adelson, chairman, chief executive and treasurer of the Las Vegas Sands Corporation, received $3.6 million in salary and bonus last year, almost $1 million more than prescribed under the company's performance plan.

articles.headline: Glass Artists Face Off in Court
articles.snippet: Dale Chihuly, a glass artist, has accused two glass blowers of imitating his creations  inspired by the sea.
articles.abstract: Dale Chihuly, a glass artist, has accused two glass blowers of imitating his creations  inspired by the sea.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE, May 31 — As an ever-moving maestro in the world where fine art and commerce converge, Dale Chihuly is perhaps the world's most successful glass artist.

articles.headline: 2 New Captains of the Economy Face Volatile Global Markets
articles.snippet: The president's choice for Treasury secretary and the Federal Reserve chief are expected to work together at a time when global markets are more erratic.
articles.abstract: The president's choice for Treasury secretary and the Federal Reserve chief are expected to work together at a time when global markets are more erratic.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 31  One reached the pinnacle of wealth and prestige as a dealmaker on Wall Street. The other was an academic superstar, brilliant but somewhat shy and more at ease in Bermuda shorts than suits.

articles.headline: 2 New Captains of the Economy Face Volatile Global Markets
articles.snippet: One reached the pinnacle of wealth and prestige as a dealmaker on Wall Street. The other was an academic superstar, brilliant but somewhat shy and more at ease in Bermuda shorts than suits.     But now they find themselves side by side in confront...
articles.abstract: One reached the pinnacle of wealth and prestige as a dealmaker on Wall Street. The other was an academic superstar, brilliant but somewhat shy and more at ease in Bermuda shorts than suits.     But now they find themselves side by side in confronting a stiff new test: helping to guide the economy from a period of fast growth and cheap money through one of higher interest rates, jittery markets and a falling dollar.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 31 - One reached the pinnacle of wealth and prestige as a dealmaker on Wall Street. The other was an academic superstar, brilliant but somewhat shy and more at ease in Bermuda shorts than suits.

articles.headline: Iraq's Premier Seeks to Control a City in Chaos
articles.snippet: Iraq's new prime minister made an urgent visit to this increasingly lawless city on Wednesday, imposing a state of emergency and ordering leaders to cease their violent struggle for power and allow order to return to this oil-rich region.     Once...
articles.abstract: Iraq's new prime minister made an urgent visit to this increasingly lawless city on Wednesday, imposing a state of emergency and ordering leaders to cease their violent struggle for power and allow order to return to this oil-rich region.     Once seemingly immune to the violence that has plagued the rest of the country, Basra Province, the heart of Iraq's Shiite south, has sunk into chaos. Shiite political parties and their militias are fighting to control the provincial government and the region's oil wealth, contributing to some of the worst rates of killing since the invasion, with 174 killings in the past two months -- double the amount from the previous two months, according to the Basra police.
articles.lead_paragraph: BASRA, Iraq, May 31 - Iraq's new prime minister made an urgent visit to this increasingly lawless city on Wednesday, imposing a state of emergency and ordering leaders to cease their violent struggle for power and allow order to return to this oil-rich region.
articles.byline: By Sabrina Tavernise and Qais Mizher

articles.headline: U.S. Makes Offer to Meet Iranians on Nuclear Plan
articles.snippet: The Bush administration said Wednesday that the United States would join Europeans in talks with Iran over its nuclear program, but only if Tehran first suspended its uranium activities, which are thought to be a cover for developing nuclear arms....
articles.abstract: The Bush administration said Wednesday that the United States would join Europeans in talks with Iran over its nuclear program, but only if Tehran first suspended its uranium activities, which are thought to be a cover for developing nuclear arms.     The declaration, by Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice, was a shift away from decades of refusal to hold broad, direct talks with Iran. But Iran has long said it would not agree to preconditions, and the administration's offer appeared to be aimed as much at placating American allies as at wooing Iran.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 31 - The Bush administration said Wednesday that the United States would join Europeans in talks with Iran over its nuclear program, but only if Tehran first suspended its uranium activities, which are thought to be a cover for developing nuclear arms.

articles.headline: Terror Fears Hamper U.S. Muslims' Travel
articles.snippet: Azhar Usman, a burly American-born Muslim with a heavy black beard, says he elicits an almost universal reaction when he boards an airplane at any United States airport: conversations stop in midsentence and the look in the eyes of his fellow pass...
articles.abstract: Azhar Usman, a burly American-born Muslim with a heavy black beard, says he elicits an almost universal reaction when he boards an airplane at any United States airport: conversations stop in midsentence and the look in the eyes of his fellow passengers says, ''We're all going to die!''     For Ahmed Ahmed, a comedian, it is even worse. His double-barreled name matches an occasional alias used by a henchman of Osama bin Laden. ''It's a bad time to be named Ahmed right now,'' he riffs in his stand-up routine, before describing being hauled through the Las Vegas airport in handcuffs.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, May 31 - Azhar Usman, a burly American-born Muslim with a heavy black beard, says he elicits an almost universal reaction when he boards an airplane at any United States airport: conversations stop in midsentence and the look in the eyes of his fellow passengers says, "We're all going to die!"

articles.headline: Big Bonuses Still Flow, Even if Bosses Miss Goals
articles.snippet: It was the kind of mistake that wage slaves can only dream of. Because of what the company called an ''improper interpretation'' of his employment contract, Sheldon G. Adelson, chairman, chief executive and treasurer of the Las Vegas Sands Corpora...
articles.abstract: It was the kind of mistake that wage slaves can only dream of. Because of what the company called an ''improper interpretation'' of his employment contract, Sheldon G. Adelson, chairman, chief executive and treasurer of the Las Vegas Sands Corporation, received $3.6 million in salary and bonus last year, almost $1 million more than prescribed under the company's performance plan.     Four more top executives of the Las Vegas Sands, which owns the Venetian Resort Hotel and Casino, received more than they should have. The total in excess bonus payments for the five men was $2.8 million.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was the kind of mistake that wage slaves can only dream of. Because of what the company called an "improper interpretation" of his employment contract, Sheldon G. Adelson, chairman, chief executive and treasurer of the Las Vegas Sands Corporation, received $3.6 million in salary and bonus last year, almost $1 million more than prescribed under the company's performance plan.

articles.headline: Saks Fifth Avenue Takes a Step Back in Search of Its Future
articles.snippet: Of all the changes that unfolded at Saks Fifth Avenue under the tumultuous three-year reign of Fred Wilson, none left shoppers and investors scratching their heads more than the elimination of Real Clothes, a popular in-house clothing label.     I...
articles.abstract: Of all the changes that unfolded at Saks Fifth Avenue under the tumultuous three-year reign of Fred Wilson, none left shoppers and investors scratching their heads more than the elimination of Real Clothes, a popular in-house clothing label.     Introduced in 1985, the line of affordable, casual apparel for women grew into a $60 million business before Mr. Wilson abruptly dropped it last year, saying the line did not fit into his vision of Saks as a luxury retailer that appealed to the young, fashion-hungry consumer.
articles.lead_paragraph: Of all the changes that unfolded at Saks Fifth Avenue under the tumultuous three-year reign of Fred Wilson, none left shoppers and investors scratching their heads more than the elimination of Real Clothes, a popular in-house clothing label.

articles.headline: For Venezuela, a Treasure in Oil Sludge
articles.snippet: The sludge in the glass jar on David Nelson's bookshelf here is thicker than molasses and was once thought worthless. But the Chevron Corporation, whose operations he runs in eastern Venezuela, has spent about $1 billion turning what was once call...
articles.abstract: The sludge in the glass jar on David Nelson's bookshelf here is thicker than molasses and was once thought worthless. But the Chevron Corporation, whose operations he runs in eastern Venezuela, has spent about $1 billion turning what was once called liquid coal into oil, helping transform a swath of scrub grass into a great frontier for oil production.      The region, the Orinoco Belt, is in fact so promising that President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela says it contains up to 235 billion barrels of recoverable oil; if true, the reserves would rival those of Saudi Arabia.

articles.headline: Sun Says It Will Cut at Least 4,000 Jobs
articles.snippet: Sun Microsystems, the struggling network computer maker, announced on Wednesday that it planned to cut 4,000 to 5,000 jobs in the next six months as it tries to return to profitability.      The cuts, which will reduce Sun's work force of 37,500 b...
articles.abstract: Sun Microsystems, the struggling network computer maker, announced on Wednesday that it planned to cut 4,000 to 5,000 jobs in the next six months as it tries to return to profitability.      The cuts, which will reduce Sun's work force of 37,500 by 11 percent to 13 percent, are the first major move by Jonathan Schwartz, who succeeded Scott McNealy as Sun's chief executive in April.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, May 31 - Sun Microsystems, the struggling network computer maker, announced on Wednesday that it planned to cut 4,000 to 5,000 jobs in the next six months as it tries to return to profitability.

articles.headline: Renting Movies With a Box and a Beam
articles.snippet: YOU know the trouble with movies in America these days? There just aren't enough ways to see them. If you miss a movie in the theater, it's gone forever -- unless you can find a video-rental store, DVD-by-mail service, cable movie station, pay-per...
articles.abstract: YOU know the trouble with movies in America these days? There just aren't enough ways to see them. If you miss a movie in the theater, it's gone forever -- unless you can find a video-rental store, DVD-by-mail service, cable movie station, pay-per-view service, video-on-demand channel, Internet movie download site, hotel room or airplane.      Thank goodness, then, that a company backed by Disney, Intel and Cisco has stepped in to fill the breach with yet another movie-delivery mechanism. It's a slim, silver, good-looking $200 set-top box called MovieBeam.
articles.lead_paragraph: YOU know the trouble with movies in America these days? There just aren't enough ways to see them. If you miss a movie in the theater, it's gone forever -- unless you can find a video-rental store, DVD-by-mail service, cable movie station, pay-per-view service, video-on-demand channel, Internet movie download site, hotel room or airplane.

articles.headline: Glass Artists Face Off in Court
articles.snippet: As an ever-moving maestro in the world where fine art and commerce converge, Dale Chihuly is perhaps the world's most successful glass artist.     His clients include Bill Gates and Bill Clinton, and his elaborate installations of sea gardens and ...
articles.abstract: As an ever-moving maestro in the world where fine art and commerce converge, Dale Chihuly is perhaps the world's most successful glass artist.     His clients include Bill Gates and Bill Clinton, and his elaborate installations of sea gardens and flower clusters show that mere sand transformed by fire can elevate a casino ceiling to the level of gallery spectacle.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE, May 31 - As an ever-moving maestro in the world where fine art and commerce converge, Dale Chihuly is perhaps the world's most successful glass artist.

articles.headline: Studies Portray Tropical Arctic in Distant Past
articles.snippet: The first detailed analysis of an extraordinary climatic and biological record from the seabed near the North Pole shows that 55 million years ago the Arctic Ocean was much warmer than scientists imagined -- a Floridian year-round average of 74 de...
articles.abstract: The first detailed analysis of an extraordinary climatic and biological record from the seabed near the North Pole shows that 55 million years ago the Arctic Ocean was much warmer than scientists imagined -- a Floridian year-round average of 74 degrees.      The findings, published today in three papers in the journal Nature, fill in a blank spot in scientists' understanding of climate history. And while they show that much remains to be learned about climate change, they suggest that scientists have greatly underestimated the power of heat-trapping gases to warm the Arctic.
